title: Suburban family outbids developers in Hampton
text:
Was it overpriced? It was a good price. The price probably reflected the changing market – it was a lot more positive than we’ve seen.

What did you think it would go for? I thought it might be around $1.8 million.

What was surprising about it? The vendors were hoping to get someone with a commercial angle - generally they pay more. But in this changing market the family who’s frustrated at the lack of stock is willing to pay more than most people.

There were three clear-cut options. Bidder #1 was a couple looking to do a renovation and flip it. Bidder #2 was a couple looking to do a side-by-side [townhouse development] which was approved. Bidder #3, the winner, was a family looking to put a family home on there.

The winning bidder, a family owner-occupier, beat two rivals who wanted to develop the site commercially.

How did the auction play out?

It had a mediocre start. People were finding their way. Then it really caught some wind once the third bidder got involved. It moved quite quickly and really took off with very strong bidding, back and forth. There was not a huge amount of think time.

When did it drop from three bidders to two?

Around the $1.87 million-mark. The final increments were in the $5000s and $1000s. It was a bit of mixed bag. They were [both final bidders] trying to lay out couple of knock-out punches, they tried and slowed down, determined not to stop on an even number.

Advertisement

Good bidding doesn’t stop on an even number. — Agent Matt Cleverdon

Some people will say “I’ve got $1.9 million to spend”. So if you bid $1,901,000, you might get it with that last $1000. Good bidding doesn’t stop on an even number.

The side-by-side [developer buyers] tried to go with a knock-out punch. They put up about $7000 at the end. They stopped at $1,910,000. The family bidder said “I won’t stop on an even number. I’ll give it one last shot”. And that was enough to get it. They won by $1000.

They said they had been looking for “quite a few months” and had been unsuccessful at a couple of other auctions. They potentially thought stock levels would be increasing, but they just hadn’t seen that. That’s forcing some of the prices up we’ve seen recently.

Do you reckon we’ll see another result like this: a) next week b) next year c) next cycle d) never?

a) Next week. We’ve seen a few of these recently. It’s a market shifting for these family dwellings.
description: In a time of low stock, frustrated owner-occupiers are even giving developers a hard run.
